security_audit.summary: This is a pure documentation skill containing only markdown files with code examples. All detected patterns are within documentation code blocks and are not executable. The skill provides reference material for implementing S3 upload functionality and poses no security risk.

content.user_title: Implement AWS S3 file uploads with ready-to-use patterns
content.value_statement: Building secure file uploads to AWS S3 requires understanding presigned URLs, client SDKs, and server-side processing. This skill provides complete documentation with UI components, client utilities, and server patterns to implement production-ready S3 uploads quickly.
actual_capabilities: Documentation for S3Uploader UI component with dropzone and button variants
ClientS3Uploader class reference for custom upload interfaces
Server-side upload utility patterns using uploadFromServer
Presigned URL API route examples for secure client uploads
Environment configuration guidance for AWS credentials
Complete code examples with TypeScript types and props
limitations: Documentation only - does not include actual component implementation files
Users must create their own API routes for presigned URL generation
Requires existing AWS S3 bucket with appropriate permissions configured
Examples assume Next.js application structure and AWS SDK v3

output_examples.input: Show me how to set up the S3Uploader component for image uploads
output: Import S3Uploader component from your UI components directory
Configure presignedRouteProvider prop with your API endpoint path
Set variant to button or dropzone based on desired UI
Add accept prop with image/* to filter file types
Implement onUpload callback to handle successful uploads
Set maxFiles and maxSize props for validation limits

output_examples.input: How do I upload files from the server side?
output: Provide file content as base64 string in file parameter
Specify destination path in S3 bucket using path parameter
Set contentType to appropriate MIME type
Function returns the public URL of uploaded file
Ensure AWS credentials are configured in environment variables

output_examples.input: What environment variables do I need to configure?
output: AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID for authentication with AWS services
AWS_REGION specifying the S3 bucket region
Add these to .env.local file for Next.js projects
Never commit credentials to version control

best_practices: Use presigned URLs to upload directly from browser to S3 without exposing AWS credentials in client code
Validate file types and sizes on both client side and server side to prevent malicious uploads
Configure appropriate S3 bucket CORS policies and access control lists based on security requirements
anti_patterns: Never expose AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY or other credentials in client-side code or public repositories
Do not skip server-side validation even with client-side checks as clients can bypass frontend validation
Avoid routing large file uploads through your application server as it wastes bandwidth and processing

faq.question: What AWS permissions are required for this to work?
faq.answer: Your S3 bucket needs s3:PutObject permission. The IAM user generating presigned URLs needs s3:PutObject and s3:GetObject permissions for the bucket.

faq.question: What is the maximum file size I can upload?
faq.answer: The documented examples use 10MB limit. You can adjust this in presigned post conditions and component maxSize prop based on your requirements.

faq.question: How do I create the API route for presigned URLs?
faq.answer: Use @aws-sdk/s3-presigned-post createPresignedPost function in a Next.js API route. The skill documentation includes a complete working example.

faq.question: Will uploaded files be publicly accessible?
faq.answer: The example sets acl to public-read. Remove this field and configure bucket policies appropriately for private file uploads.

faq.question: Why am I getting CORS errors during upload?
faq.answer: Your S3 bucket needs CORS configuration allowing PUT and POST methods from your application domain origin.

faq.question: What is the benefit of presigned URLs over direct uploads?
faq.answer: Presigned URLs allow browser to upload directly to S3, bypassing your server bandwidth and eliminating processing bottlenecks for large files.
